entry.title: Transparency in qualitative research
entry.summary: 3 meetings during spring 2020 led by Thomas Hillman
entry.content:
3 meetings during spring 2020 led by Thomas Hillman

Transparency & replicability

April 17th 10:30-12:00 

Kapiszewski, D., & Karcher, S. (2019). Transparency in Practice in Qualitative Research.

Aguinis, H., & Solarino, A. M. (2019). Transparency and replicability in qualitative research: The case of interviews with elite informants. Strategic Management Journal.

Pratt, M. G., Kaplan, S., & Whittington, R. (2019). Editorial Essay: The Tumult over Transparency: Decoupling Transparency from Replication in Establishing Trustworthy Qualitative Research. Administrative Science Quarterly, 0001839219887663.

Preregistration

May 8th 10:30-12:00

L. Haven, T., & Van Grootel, D. L. (2019). Preregistering qualitative research. Accountability in research, 26(3), 229-244.

Kern, F. G., & Gleditsch, K. S. (2017). Exploring Pre-Registration and Pre-Analysis Plans for Qualitative Inference. Preprint ahead of publication, 1-15. 

Hartman, A., Kern, F., & Mellor, D. T. (2019, September 13). Preregistration for Qualitative Research Template.

Open datasets & reporting

May 29th 10:30-12:00

Branney, P., Reid, K., Frost, N., Coan, S., Mathieson, A., & Woolhouse, M. (2018, October 31). A meta-framework for designing open data studies in psychology: ethical and practical issues of open qualitative data sets.

Tong, A., Sainsbury, P., & Craig, J. (2007). Consolidated criteria for reporting qualitative research (COREQ): a 32-item checklist for interviews and focus groups. International journal for quality in health care, 19(6), 349-357.

entry.title: Platformization & education
entry.summary: 3 meetings during spring 2020 led by Thomas Hillman
entry.content:
3 meetings during spring 2020 led by Thomas Hillman

Conceptualizing platforms

February 7th 10:30-12:00

Bogost, I., & Montfort, N. (2009). Platform studies: Frequently questioned answers.

Gillespie, T. (2010). The politics of ‘platforms’. New media & society, 12(3), 347-364.

Plantin, J. C., Lagoze, C., Edwards, P. N., & Sandvig, C. (2018). Infrastructure studies meet platform studies in the age of Google and Facebook. New Media & Society, 20(1), 293-310.

Schooling

February 27th 15:00-16:30

Selwyn, N. (2016). ‘There’s so much data’: Exploring the realities of data-based school governance. European Educational Research Journal, 15(1), 54-68. 

Kumar, P. C., Vitak, J., Chetty, M., & Clegg, T. L. (2019). The Platformization of the Classroom: Teachers as Surveillant Consumers. Surveillance & Society, 17(1/2), 145-152.

Williamson, B. (2017). Learning in the ‘platform society’: Disassembling an educational data assemblage. Research in Education, 98(1), 59-82.

Manolev, J., Sullivan, A., & Slee, R. (2019). The datafication of discipline: ClassDojo, surveillance and a performative classroom culture. Learning, Media and Technology, 44(1), 36-51.

Lifelong learning

March 20th 10:30-12:00

Lehdonvirta, V., Margaryan, A. & Dvies, H. (2019). Skills formation and skills matching in online platform work: policies and practices for promoting crowdworkers’ continuous learning (CrowdLearn). Europeam Centre for the Development of Vocational Training.

Kelkar, S. (2018). On the “Neutrality” of Platforms: How the Platform Shapes Pedagogy in MOOCs. Anthropology Now, 10(3), 70-83.

Means, A. J. (2018). Platform learning and on-demand labor: sociotechnical projections on the future of education and work. Learning, Media and Technology, 43(3), 326-338.

entry.title: Mona Lundin
entry.summary: Mona Lundin is Associate Professor at the Department of Education, Communication and Learning at the University of Gothenburg. Her research concerns learning and knowledge in professional activities.
entry.content:
Mona Lundin is Associate Professor at the Department of Education, Communication and Learning at the University of Gothenburg. Her research concerns learning and knowledge in professional activities.

  • BalancED (Co-Investigator)
  • SOCDEX (PhD Supervisor)

Mona's dissertation project (funded by LearnIT in collaboration with the Knowledge Foundation), “New Web-based Educational Environments as Contexts for Interaction and Learning for Professionals,” the focus was on how professionals participate in and make use of Web-based educational platforms designed to facilitate various types of continuing education and professional development efforts. The main point was to analyse activities being developed in these new contexts for learning. What learning and discourse cultures are being established in these contexts?

entry.title: Catarina Player-Koro
entry.summary: Catarina Player-Koro is Associate Professor at the Department of Pedagogical, Curricular and Professional Studies at the University of Gothenburg. Her main research interest includes critical sociological studies of educational technology and educational policy studies, with a special interest in teachers work and teacher education.
entry.content:
Catarina Player-Koro is Associate Professor at the Department of Pedagogical, Curricular and Professional Studies at the University of Gothenburg. Her main research interest includes critical sociological studies of educational technology and educational policy studies, with a special interest in teachers work and teacher education.

  • BalancED (Co-Investigator)

Catarina is currently active in research in the policy fields in studies on policy network formations, connecting public and commercial interests and actors within IT education policy an in investigating the policy effects of the implementation of career pathways for teachers, in Swedish schools.

entry.content:
